texts.en:
Pilar is 56 years old and married with 10 children. With four children in school, Pilar works very hard to provide for them.

Pilar runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional items to sell like canned goods, beverages, groceries, etc.

Pilar has been in this business for 15 years and sells a variety of items. 

In the future, Pilar would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell like canned goods, beverages, groceries, etc.

loans.name: Saratu

texts.en: Saratu is a maize farmer from Dogon Fako village in Kaduna state. Before she became a Babban Gona member, Saratu would have had to sell her maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for her immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Saratu can now store her maize at harvest time, and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Saratu, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand her farmland, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in her community.

loans.use: To buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn at low prices at harvest

loans.name: Marichu

texts.en:
Marichu is a woman with one child. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Marichu is 25 years old now.

Marichu has a direct selling of beauty and household products business in the Philippines. Marichu requested a PHP 5,000 loan through NWTF to buy more beauty and household products for retailing.

Marichu has been in this business for three years. In the future, Marichu would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more beauty and household products for retailing

loans.name: Tone Kwa Village Group

texts.en:
Located in Tone Kwa Village, in Myanmar's Ayeyarwaddy Delta region, this community consist of 25 village members (Female 16, Male 9), includes 5 CBO members (Community Based Organizations) who helping to lead the loan in certain area.

This loan will help villagers purchase more ducks which will let them increase income from more duck eggs and help the villagers buy good quality duck foods (a packet costs $14, 4 days provisions for 100 ducks). The villagers earn their living from crop farms and fishing as they have streams nearby from their home. Most married women help their husband on the farm as well as look after the home raised livestock. Some families have small grocery stores open in their house. For livestock, villagers mostly raise pigs, hens and ducks.

The above is the picture of 5 CBO members, named as Daw Yu, U Myint, U Moe and Daw Tin. Daw Yu, included in the picture (second from left), is 21 years old. She is married and living happily together with her husband. Her husband farms at their 7 acres of crop farm whereas she looks after to their 100 ducks. Even though there are very least members in the family, they are having financial problems and in need for investments. The current 100 ducks aren't enough and so with this loan, she wants to increase the number of ducks to 130.

loans.use: To help the villagers purchase ducks as well as high quality feeds.

loans.name: Pae Kone Village Group 1

texts.en:
Located in Pae Kone Village, Myanmar's Ayeyarwaddy Delta region and this community consists of 26 female members, includes 5 CBO (Community Based Organization) members who lead the loan in certain areas.

This loan will help the villagers buy Taiwan (named) ducks which are much bigger in size as well lay eggs very often. Even though, Taiwan ducks ($6 per duck) are much more expensive than normal ducks, this lets them earn more while selling the eggs. Likewise, this loan will help some of the members to buy good quality feeds and vitamins. Pae Kone Villagers specialize on both crop farming and fishing as the streams nearby from the homes. Some earn from boat carries as well as from plantations such as betel and seasonal fruits. Additionally, most have pigs and ducks as livestock.

The picture above are the CBO members from Pae Kone Village, named as, Daw Khin, Daw Nyein, Daw Than, Daw Ae and Daw Aye.

Included in the picture, Daw Khine (First from left), is 42 years old. She is married and blessed having 3 daughters. Her husband is a fisherman and she mostly take care of her 160 ducks and 4 pigs. Like other fellow members, this loan will help her buy foods for her Taiwan ducks.

loans.use: To help the villagers purchase ducks, good quality feeds and vitamins.

loans.name: Pae Kone Village Group 2

texts.en:
Located in Pae Kone Village, Myanmar's Ayeyarwaddy Delta region and this community consist of 26 members,includes 5 CBO (Community Based Organization) members who lead the loan in certain areas.

This loan will help the villagers buy Taiwan (named) ducks which are much bigger in size as well lay eggs very often. Even though, Taiwan ducks ($6 per duck) are much expensive than normal ducks, this let them earn more while selling the eggs. Likewise, this loan will help some of the members to buy good quality feeds and vitamins.Pae Kaung Villagers specialize on both crop farming and fishing as the streams nearby from the homes. Some earn from boat carries as well as from plantations such as betel and seasonal fruits. Besides, most have pigs and ducks as livestock.

The picture above are the CBO members from Pae Kaung Village, named as, Daw Thin, U San, U Kyaw, U Khin and U Po.Daw Thin, included in the picture, (First from right) is 40 years old. She is married having 3 children. Her husband takes of their 6 acres crop farm and she spends her day looking after the livestock as well as a small gocery shop. From the loan, she wants to buy high quality feeds for ducks. By feeding enough and keeping the ducks happy let villagers have increase income as they get more duck eggs.

loans.use: To help the villagers purchase ducks, good quality feeds and vitamins.

loans.name: Sokha

texts.en: A woman living in Kampong Cham province, Sokha is 56 years old and a mother of seven children. For her family, she grows rice on three hectares of land and raises pigs to earn more income. This is her first time with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). She will spend her entire loan portion to buy rice seed and pay for harvesting fee. She hopes that she can improve her rice farm better than before.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and pay for harvesting fee.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Cheung Prey district

loans.name: Dan

texts.en: Dan would like to take a further loan to buy a greater variety and quantity of medicines to sell from her store. Dan's previous loan enabled her to increase her sales and earn a higher income to support her family. She hopes that another loan will assist her in increasing the size of her business, attract new customers and increase sales. She also hopes that through the loan she can increase her income and improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy a greater variety and quantity of medicines to sell

loans.name: Jorge Isaac

texts.es:
Consolas y variados videos juegos están a la disposición a todo público en el pequeño hogar de Jorge Isaac de 21 años. Bajo supervisión de sus padres inicio su propio negocio con un televisor y una consola que logro comprar con sus ahorros. Hoy en día ha logrado diversificar su negocio con nuevos  video juegos que logren recrear a sus clientes y a la misma vez le proporcionen ingresos. A causa del surgimiento  de nuevos  esparcimientos  en el mercado  solicita préstamo para comprar equipos que cautiven a sus clientes y los mantenga fieles.

Jorge Isaac afirma que desde pequeño es un  gran aficionado de la tecnología y considera que  los videojuegos más que un entretenimiento ayudan a  potenciar la creatividad y la imaginación de las personas. Entre sus planes esta amplificar el espacio que actualmente conserva  y  abrir otro negocio de videojuegos en los alrededores. El alto nivel de entusiasmo que posee lo motiva a querer superarse cada día más.
texts.en:
Consoles and a variety of video games are available to everyone in the small home of Jorge Isaac, who is 21 years old. Under the supervision of his parents, he opened his own business with a television and a console, which he managed to buy with his savings. Today, he has managed to diversify his business with new video games, which entertain his clients, and at the same time, provide income. Because of the surge in new forms of recreation in the market, he asks for a loan to purchase equipment that will captivate his clients, and keep them faithful.
Jorge Isaac says that since he was young, he was enthusiastic about technology, and he considers video games more than entertainment, as they help to strengthen creativity and imagination in people. Among his plans is to enlarge the space he currently keeps, and to open another video game business in the surrounding area. The high level of enthusiasm he possesses motivates him to want to improve more every day.

loans.use: to purchase entertainment equipment

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en: Emmanuel is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Emmanuel joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children Linus, Lovina and Christopher.  Before he became a Babban Gona member, Emmanuel would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Emmanuel can now store his maize at harvest time, and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked, Emmanuel  spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to pay for school fees and uniforms for his children, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Yusuf

texts.en: Yusuf is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Yusuf joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Ketura, Comfort and Elcana. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Yusuf would have to sell his maize at low prices soon after harvest to cater to his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Yusuf can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked, Yusuf  spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to ensure his children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: To pay for school fees and uniforms, which will eliminate the pressure to sell corn at low prices during harvest.

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
As a married parent of two children, Marivic works hard to support her family.

She has a vegetables vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from general store. Marivic is borrowing PHP 6000 through NWTF to buy more vegetables to sell for her vegetables vending business.

Marivic has been sustaining her business activities through her past 3 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Chanthol's Group

texts.en: Chanthol, 36, lives with family members in a rural village of the Kampong Cham province and a mother of three schoolchildren. For her family condition, she plants tobaccos as a single main source of her income. She can earn income about 38,800 KHR per day. This is first time for Chanthol with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). In a group of two members, she is a group leader. She will spend her entire loan portion to buy fertilizer to support her tobaccos farm. She hopes that she can improve her farm better than before.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to support her tobaccos farm.

location.town: Kampong Cham Province, Koh Sotin District

loans.name: Pha Yar Yoe Village Group

texts.en:
This community is located in Myanmar Ayeyarwaddy's Delta region, and the group consist of 28 members (17 Females, 11 Males), including 5 CBO (Community Based Organizations) members who are leading the loans in certain area.
This loan will help the villagers, purchase ducks and buy high quality feeds ($12 per packet). As a packet lasts for only a week, the villagers have to buy every week to make the duck's life a healthy living. If the ducks are kept happily and nutritious, 60% of ducks in average lay eggs every day. More duck's eggs mean more income to villagers.
The men from Phar Yar Yoe Village, are mostly famers and the women, they plant colorful flowers and sell in the market from town early morning. Besides from crop farming, they spend their whole life through fishing and raising livestock such as pigs, ducks, goats and hens. Some village customers as well have small grocery store up through in the stream.
The picture above, are the CBO members from this area, named as, Daw Khin, U Myint, U Kyi, U Maung and Daw Pa. Included in the picture, Daw Khin (second from right), is 37 years old. She is married and blessed having 3 children. Her husband works in the city ship and comes back to village twice in a year. She earns from boat riding from town to village every day and vice versa. But now, she is happy that her eldest son is helping her along both taking care of the livestock, pigs and ducks. This loan would help her buy more 50 ducks and enough feeds which will help her increase the income.

loans.use: To help the villagers from Pha Yar Yoe Village Group purchase ducks as well as high quality feeds.

loans.name: Thate Che Village Group 1

texts.en:
This community is located in Thate Che Village in Myanmar's Ayeyarwaddy Delta region. The community consists of 30 village customers (23 females, 7 males), and includes five Community Based Organization members (CBOs) who are helping to lead the loans. This new loan will help villagers buy ducklings (each duckling costs $2.70), build duck farms, and buy a boat (the boat costs $40) to look after the ducklings. Some villagers also plan to buy food for ducklings, which costs $14 per packet, and is a week's feed for 100 ducklings. 

Most of the villagers from Thate Che Village earn from crop farms. To have extra income, some cut firewood or bamboo to sell in the market. Some as well plant betel, and for livestock, as the steams are nearby their house, they mostly raise ducks or pigs. Pictured above are the CBOs from this village, named Daw Chu, U Thein, U Nyo, U Kyaw and Daw Tin. 

Daw Chu, involved in the picture (first from left), is 43 years old. She is married and has six sons (five are students and one works in the city). She works as a daily worker and sometimes helps her husband to look after the ducks. Her husband is a farmer but he currently has to rent others' farms, as they have financial problems in buying a farm. She raises ducks as well as some pigs as livestock.

loans.use: to help the villagers from Thate Che Village Group 1 purchase ducklings, and at the same time to build up the duck farm.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
As a married parent of five children, Lucia works hard to support her family.

She has a fishing business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from fish vending. Lucia is borrowing PHP 13,000 through NWTF to buy fishing materials like fishing net, bamboo, gasoline, etc. for her fishing business.

Lucia has been sustaining her business activities through her past six loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy fishing materials like fishing net, bamboo, gasoline, etc.

loans.name: Alexis

texts.en: Alexis, age 33, is married with six children between the ages of 4 and 13. All of them go to school. He has a shop and has been in business for 11 years. With the loan, he would like to buy more cooking oil and salt to resell. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees for his children.

loans.use: To buy more cooking oil and salt to resell.

loans.name: Tu Myaung Village Group

texts.en:
Located in Tu Myaung Village in Myanmar's Delta region and the community consist of 25 members (19 Females and 6 Males), includes 5 CBO (Community Based Organizations) that are leading the loans in certain area.
This loan would help the villagers from Tu Myaung Village, purchase ducks and high quality nutritious feeds ($13 per packet). ). As a packet lasts for only a week for 100 ducks, the villagers have to buy every week to make the duck's life a healthy living. If the ducks are kept happily and nutritious, 60% of ducks in average lay eggs every day. More duck's eggs mean more income to villagers.
The villagers mostly are crop farmers and others, as well do the fishing since the stream water flows nearby the houses. Meanwhile, they plant colorful flowers, coconuts and betel which they sell at morning market from town. Nearly every house in the village raise pigs, hens, goats and ducks as livestock.
The above picture, are the CBOs of Tu Myaung Village Group, named as, Daw Khin, U Khin (M), Daw Aung, Daw Zin and Daw Aye.
Included in the picture, Daw Khin (First from left) is 33 years old. She is a housewife having four children. Her husband farms at their 6 acres owned crop farm. While staying at home whole day, she looks after the 105 ducks and a pig. Furthermore, they as well plant the betel and coconut. With the loan, she wants to have more 50 ducks and enough feeds.

loans.use: To help the villagers from Tu Myaung Village Group purchase ducks and good high quality feeds.

loans.name: Lien

texts.en: Lien would like to take a further loan to buy gas tanks and gas cookers to sell from her store. Her previous loan enabled her to increase her sales and earn a higher income to support her family. She hopes that another loan will assist her in increasing the size of her business, attract new customers and increase sales. She also hopes that through the loan she can increase her income and improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy gas tanks and gas cookers for selling for her fuel and firewood business.

loans.name: Xoan

texts.en: Xoan would like to take a further loan to buy better quality leather to make belts to sell from her shop. Xoan's previous loan enabled her to increase her sales and earn a higher income to support her family. She hopes that another loan will assist her in increasing the size of her business, attract new customers, and increase sales. She also hopes that through the loan she can increase her income and improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy leather to make belts.

loans.name: Rosa Maria

texts.es: Con ganas de salir adelante y satisfecha con el primer crédito obtenido Doña Rosa solicita un segundo crédito para aumentar el inventario y ofrecer mayor variedad en su pulpería. Solicita el crédito para comprar arroz, frijoles, golosinas, gaseosas entre otros productos. Este crédito le ayudara a obtener mejores ingresos y así lograr solventar sus necesidades básicas, de esta forma lograra ser auto sostenible.
texts.en:
Eager to get ahead and satisfied with the first loan she obtained, Ms. Rosa requests a second loan to increase her inventory and to offer more variety in her store. 

She is requesting a loan to buy rice, beans, candy, soft drinks and other products. 

This loan will help her earn a better income to be able to meet her basic needs, and achieve self-sufficiency.

loans.use: to buy rice, beans, candy, soft drinks and other products..

loans.name: Yohanna

texts.en: Yohanna is a maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Yohanna would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Yohanna can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Like other Babban Gona members, Yohanna is looking  to earn a better income to provide more food and clothing for his family, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: To buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn at low prices at harvest

loans.name: Lia

texts.en: Lia is 36 years old. She is married and lives with her husband and pensioner mother-in-law. The family is involved in agricultural activities. In particular, they own a plot of land, where they grow maize and strawberries seasonally and sell the harvested products locally. Lia is very hardworking young woman and does her best to ensure a good harvest. She wants to start an additional business and requested a loan. The Start up program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo enables her to get a loan of 1,300 GEL. With the received credit, she will start a mushroom business. She will grow mushrooms on the unused land and will sell them. This will increase her family income.

loans.use: to grow mushrooms on an unused land and increase family income.

loans.name: Bala Laure

texts.en: Bala Laure is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Bala Laure joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children Hassan, Hussaini and Rahab.  Before he became a Babban Gona member, Bala Laure would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Bala Laure can now store his maize at harvest time, and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked, Bala Laure spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to make more money for himself and his family.

loans.use: to pay for children's school fees and uniforms, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Uyung

texts.en:
Hello, lenders! Meet Uyung, one of the Ruma agents who lives in East Serang, a suburban city located about three hours' drive from Jakarta. Uyung is happily married, and he and his wife have been blessed with one child. As a main job, Uyung works as an honorary teacher in an elementary school, but he also runs an independently-owned shop that sells various sport wares, such as shoes and balls. Other products he sells in his small shop include  mobile phone sim cards, mobile phone airtime credits, and utility bill payment service. He started the business because he wanted to gain a more stable income for his family; as of right now, the income from being honorary teacher is uncertain. His willingness to improve was what brought him to be introduced to a Ruma field staff. He then decided to join as a Ruma agent.

Now as the business runs, the number of mobile transactions in his shop is increasing, and he needs more working capital to fulfill it. Therefore, he hopes to get a working capital loan from Kiva in order to process such transactions in his community. In the photo, Uyung is sitting in his small shop. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to provide more mobile services in his community

loans.name: Mad Sakam

texts.en:
Hello, lenders! Meet Mad Sakam. He is a micro entrepreneur in East Serang, a suburban city located about three hours from Jakarta. He runs a small stall located in front of his family home that sells snacks, drinks, mobile phone airtime credits, and utility bill payment services. Mad Sakam is single and lives together with his parents. He is a hardworking and friendly person. 

He met a Ruma field staff member about four months ago and was excited to become a Ruma agent. He decided to join Ruma because he wanted to improve his skills in doing business with mobile technology. The demand for mobile transactions is increasing and Mad Sakam hopes to get a working capital loan from Kiva in order to process those transactions.  

In the future, he plans to add one more product from Ruma, which is e-commerce for low-income communities, a new business model from Ruma that helps people get access to good quality products with better prices. The products range from fashion products, to house and kitchen wares, to gadgets and school supplies. To buy something, people only have to pick what they want to buy from the product list in the catalog. After that, they can go to Mad Sakam or any other certified Ruma agent nearby their houses to make an order and payment. The product will be delivered right to the customer’s door.

loans.use: to provide more mobile services in his community

loans.name: Liana Nohemi

texts.es:
La tortilla durante muchos años ha sido uno de los alimentos favoritos para complementar un buen plato de comida en nuestro país. Desde hace 5 años Liana Nohemí se ha encargado de producir este suministro  para que llegue hasta el hogar de cada uno de sus clientes. A sus 34 años de edad palmea todas las mañanas la mayor cantidad posible de tortillas para obtener mayores ganancias e invertirlas en su negocio. Su meta a corto plazo en estos momentos es alcanzar el doble de productividad, por eso solicita el préstamo para comprar el doble de cantidad de granos de maíz  y cal.  
 Uno de los sueños de Liana es llegar a ser una persona autosuficiente, comprende que todo negocio tiene altos y bajos, pero está segura de que su actitud luchadora le ayudara a manejar cualquier situación. Por ahora su misión es aprovechar  al máximo el crédito y el apoyo de su familia para trabajar  duro y lograr el sueño de su propia industria.
texts.en:
For many years, the tortilla has been one of the favorite foods to complement a good meal in our country. For five years, Liana Nohemi has been in charge of producing this supply so that it reaches the home of each of her clients. At her 34 years of age, every morning she makes as many tortillas as possible to obtain better income and invest it in her business. Her short-term plan in this moment is to double her productivity. This is why she asks for a loan, to purchase double the amount of maize grain and lime powder. 
One of Liana’s dreams is to be self-sufficient. She understand that every business has its highs and lows, but she is sure that her determined attitude will help her to handle any situation. For now, her mission is to take maximum advantage of her loan and the help of her family to work hard and achieve the dream of having her own shop.

loans.use: to purchase double the amount of maize grain and lime powder to make tortillas.

loans.name: Edi

texts.en:
Hello, lenders! Meet Edi, one of Ruma agents who live in East Serang, a suburban city located about 3 hours’ drive from Jakarta. He runs a small stall located in front of his family home that sells mobile phone airtime credits and utility bill payment service. Edi is happily married, and he and his wife have been blessed with one daughter. He started the business because he wanted to gain a more stable income for his family; for right now, the income from being an honorary teacher is uncertain. His willingness to improve was what brought him to be introduced to a Ruma field staff. He then decided to join as a Ruma agent.

Now as the business runs, the number of mobile transaction in his shop is increasing and he needs more working capital to fulfill it. Therefore, he hopes to get a working capital loan from Kiva in order to process such transactions in his community. In the photo, Edi is standing in front of his house, where he placed his small stall. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to provide more mobile services in his community

loans.name: Ignacia Rebecca

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Ignacia Rebecca works hard to support her family.

She has a fishing business in the Philippines and earns additional income from fish vending. Ignacia Rebecca is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF to buy fish nets and other materials to use in her business.

Ignacia Rebecca has been sustaining her business activities through her past six loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy fish nets and other materials to use in her business

loans.name: Thate Che Village Group 2

texts.en:
This community is located in Thate Che Village in Myanmar Ayeyarwaddy's Delta region with 2200 populations. There are 26 village customers, and five Community Based Organizations (CBOs) members who are helping to lead the loans in this area. From this loan, villagers intend to buy boats to take good care of the ducks, rebuild their unstructured duck farms, and purchase high-quality duck feeds (these cost $14 per packet, and are four days feed for 100 ducks).

Everyone in the village earns from crop farms, and also plants betel and seasonal fruits. Most women in the village are housewives, and while at home, they look after their home-raised livestock such as pigs, goats and ducks. As there are no governmental lights, villagers only use candles or battery lights. 

Above is the picture of the CBOs from Thate Che Village Group 2. Their names are U Aye, Daw Ma, Daw Aye, U Zaw and U Saung. U Aye, included in the picture (second from left), is 43 years old. He is married and lives together with 11 family members. For income, he works on his five acres of crop farm, meanwhile he raises 120 ducks and a pig as livestock. Same as other members, he plans to purchase good quality feeds and boats to take good care of ducks.

loans.use: To help the villagers from Thate Che Village Group 2 purchase high quality feeds for ducks and rebuild the duck farms

loans.name: Makhfirat

texts.ru: Махфират медик по образованию. Она работает медсестрой в центральной больнице своего района Шахристон. Ей 47 лет. Махфират замужем и имеет троих сыновей. Старший сын Мухриддин студент, а двое младших сыновей учатся в школе. Мухриддин учится в дневном отделении Таджикского Университета Права, Бизнеса и Политики и в этом году перешел на второй курс. По контракту его годовое обучение в ВУЗе стоит более тысяча долларов США. В этом году семья Махфират имеет финансовые трудности и в связи с этим не смогла оплатить за учебу Мухриддина. Махфират хочет, чтобы ее сын успешно окончил ВУЗ и поэтому просит в кредит необходимую сумму для оплаты за его обучение. Она надеется финансовую поддержку с вашей стороны.
texts.en: Makhfirat is a doctor by training.  She works as a nurse in the central hospital of the Shahriston district, where she lives.  She is 47 years old, married, and the mother of three children.  Her oldest son, named Mukhriddin, is a university student, and her two younger children are still in school.  Mukhriddin studies full-time at the Tajik University of Law, Business and Politics, and he is now in his second year.  His annual tuition fees amount to more than 1,000 USD, but because the family is experiencing financial difficulties this year, Makhfirat cannot pay for her son's tuition.  However, she wants to see her son successfully complete his studies, and for this reason she is taking a loan corresponding to the sum of money that she needs to pay his tuition.  She is counting on your financial support.

loans.use: to pay for her son's higher education tuition fees.

loans.name: Sani

texts.en: Sani is a maize farmer from Gwanki village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Sani would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Sani can now store his maize at harvest time, and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Sani, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to ensure his children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: To buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn at low prices at harvest

loans.name: Xenia Marili

texts.es:
La señora Xenia de 25  años de edad, vive con su esposo y su hija   en su casa propia, se dedica desde hace 5 años al negocio de venta de Golosinas  como enchiladas, tacos, tortillas con quesillo, nachos, chilaquiles, pastelitos, etc. vive en una comunidad al sur de Honduras, es una mujer emprendedora con deseos de salir adelante y lucha día con día para mejorar su calidad de vida. 
Doña Xenia está solicitando el préstamo para compra de productos como, pollo, carnes, papas, plátanos, arroz, queso, platos desechables, frescos, agua y una mesa plástica para atender a sus clientes,  con el apoyo de este préstamo pretende mejorar sus ingresos y también su calidad de vida, es un cliente nuevo  con deseos de trabajar con Prisma.
Su sueño es tener un buen negocio y aumentar su clientela  y al mismo  tiempo mejorar su futuro junto a su familia.

San Lorenzo, Honduras - Noviembre 2014.
texts.en:
Sra. Xenia is 25 years old and resides in her own home along with her husband and daughter. For the past five years, she has been selling snacks such as enchiladas, tacos, tortillas with cheese, nachos, chilaquiles, turnovers, and other items. Xenia lives in a community in southern Honduras. She is an enterprising woman who has the drive to succeed, so she strives each day to improve her quality of life.

Doña Xenia is requesting a loan in order to buy supplies such as chicken, meats, potatoes, plantains, rice, cheese, disposable plates, soft drinks, water, and a plastic table so that she can serve her customers. With the help of this loan, she intends to improve her earnings as well as her quality of life. Xenia is a new client who wants to work with Prisma.

Her dream is to have a good business, increase her clientele, and at the same time improve the future for herself and her family.

San Lorenzo, Honduras – November 2014

loans.use: to buy chicken, meats, potatoes, plantains, rice, cheese, disposable plates, soft drinks, water, and a table for her business.

loans.name: Lorena Patricia

texts.es:
EL Grupo De Crédito La Negrita se reúne cada quince días en el Cantón Montecristi, conocido por su rica cultura pre colonial y por su artesanía, que es reconocida a nivel nacional e internacional. Lugar de los famosos sombreros de paja toquilla.
En este lugar vive la señora Lorena, tiene 43 años de edad, está separada y de esa relación tienen tres hijos, dos de ellos ya mayores de edad,  la menor tiene 15 años de edad la cual estudian en colegio, con ella también vive una nieta de 6 años que es como su hija ya que la tiene desde pequeñita y estudia en escuela.
Doña Lorena es una mujer muy trabajadora que  para salir adelante se dedica al comercio, vende ropa, zapatos, sabanas, joyas, juguetes entre otros productos, ella se desplaza hasta la ciudad de Cuenca a comprar las joyas y a Huaquillas a comprar la ropa ya que allá consigue a menor precio, su forma de venta es puerta a puerta, ella sale tres o cuatro veces por semana y también vende en su casa, ella  deja a crédito y  cobra por semanas, ya son más de 16 años que se dedica al comercio con el cual se gana el sustento diario de su familia.
Este crédito es para comprar ropa, sabanas, juguetes y todo de lo que ella vende. Lleva 3 años en el Grupo De Crédito y le gusta por la ayuda que recibe con  los créditos. Sus sueños son darles la mejor educación a sus hijas.
texts.en:
The loan group La Negrita meets every fifteen days in the canton of Montecristi, which is known for its rich pre-colonial culture and artisan products, which are recognized on a national and international level. This place is famous for its woven straw hats. 

In this place lives Lorena who is 43 years old. She is separated and has three children from that relationship. Two of them are now grown, and the youngest is 15 years old and is in school. A granddaughter who is 6 and is like a daughter to Lorena also has lived with her since she was little, and she is in school. 

Lorena is a very hardworking woman who works in sales in order to get ahead. She sells clothing, shoes, sheets, jewelry and toys among other products. She goes all the way to the city of Cuenca to purchase the jewelry, and to Huaquillas to purchase clothing because she gets it there at a lower price. She sells door to door, going out three or four times each week. She also sells from her home. She sells on credit and collects payments weekly. She has been doing this work for over 16 years and this is how she supports her family.

This loan will be used to purchase clothing, sheets and toys and all other items that she sells. Lorena has been in the loan group for 3 years now, and she likes the help she gets along with the loans. Her dreams are to give the best education she can to her children.

loans.use: to purchase items such as clothing, sheets and toys.

loans.name: Bitrus Magaji

texts.en: Bitrus Magaji is a maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Bitrus Magaji would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Bitrus Magaji can now store his maize at harvest time, and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Like other Babban Gona members, Bitrus Magaji is looking to earn a better income to provide more food and clothing for his family, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Musa

texts.en: Musa is a maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Musa would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Musa can now store his maize at harvest time, and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Like other Babban Gona members, Musa is looking to earn a better income to provide more food and clothing for his family, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing for his family, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Oysara

texts.ru: Ее зовут Ойсара. Ей 54 года. Она замужем и имеет детей. Ее муж строитель. Сама Ойсара занимается животноводством, как и многие жители Республики. Она продвигает свой бизнес уже 10 лет. У нее не так много скотов и бизнес не большой. Ойсара хочет это исправить и расширить бизнес. По этой причине она обратилась за кредитом. Ойсара хочет создать устойчивый бизнес, стать независимой женщиной и принести в дом хороший доход. Ойсара верит в себя и Вас, что Вы поможете ей в ее достижениях.
texts.en: Meet Oysara, a 54-year-old married woman and mother.  Oysara's husband works in construction while she is involved in animal husbandry, like many residents of the Tajik republic.  Oysara has been running her business for ten years already.  She doesn't own many head of cattle, and her business is quite small.  However, she wants to change things and expand her activity.  For this reason, she is taking a loan.  She wants to create a sustainable business, become financially independent and bring home a good income.  She believes in herself and in you, and trusts that you will help her achieve her goals.

loans.use: to expand her animal husbandry activity.

loans.name: Glory Glen

texts.en:
Glory Glen is 37 years old, married with six children who are in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. She has a buy-and-sell rice business in the Philippines. Glory Glen requested a PHP 17,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of rice to sell.

She has been in this business for five years. In the future, Glory Glen would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of rice to sell.

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children, Margarita works hard to support her family.

She has a food-vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from a general store. Margarita is borrowing 6,000 PHP through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food-production business.

Margarita has been sustaining her business activities through her past one loan from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food-production business

loans.name: Ravy's Group

texts.en:
Residing in the Kampong Cham province, Ravy is 22 years old and single. She opened a hair salon to earn income to support her living conditions. 

For Ravy, this is her first time with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). She leads a group of two to get a new loan. As the group leader, she will spend her loan portion to buy more materials to support her hair salon. She hopes that she can expand her business as well improve her lifestyle.

loans.use: to buy more materials to support her hair salon.

location.town: Kampong Cham Province, Koh Sotin District

loans.name: Taw Ka Yan Lay Village Group 1

texts.en:
Located in Taw Ka Yan Lay Village in Myanmar Ayeyarwaddy's Delta region, the community consists of 21 village customers. Five CBO (Community Based Organizations) members are helping to lead the loans in certain areas. From this loan, villagers would be able to purchase ducks and good-quality feeds (1 packet costs $12 and is 4 days of food for 100 ducks). For some members, this loan would help to rebuild their unstructured duck farms. More  ducks would let them have increased income from more duck eggs.

Most villagers here are farmers that specialize on cropping as well as seasonal fruits or vegetables. Almost all married women are housewives and open grocery stores at home, as well taking care of the home-raised livestock such as ducks, hens or pigs. Some girls work as a tailor in the town and come back to the village once a month.

The picture above shows the five CBOs from this village, named Daw Ei, U Win, U Moe, U Soe and Daw Cho. Daw Ei, included in the picture (first from right) is 36 years old. She lives together with four brothers and is currently farming on 18 acres of her family farm. Besides farming, she also well plants seasonal fruits and raises 100 ducks. With this loan, she wants to expand the number of ducks from 100 to 150 (a duck costs $3) and purchase high-quality feeds.

loans.use: To help 21 villagers from Taw Ka Yan Lay Village Group purchase ducks, as well as to rebuild unstructured duck farms

borrowers.first_name: Taw Ka Yan Lay Village Group 1

loans.name: Nena

texts.en:
Nena is a married woman with four children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Nena is 50 years old and one of her children is in school.

Nena has a food-vending business in the Philippines. She has requested a 6,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food-production business.

Nena has been in this business for one year. In the future, she would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food-production business

loans.name: Trang

texts.en: Trang would like to take a further loan to buy material to make bathing scrubs to sell from her stall. Trang's previous loan enabled her to increase her sales and earn a higher income to support her family. She hopes that another loan will assist her in increasing the size of her business, attract new customers and increase sales. She also hopes that through the loan she can increase her income and improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase net materials and related equipment to produce and sell bathing scrub products.

loans.name: Taw Ka Yan Lay Village Group 2

texts.en:
Located in Taw Ka Yan Lay Village in Myanmar Ayeyarwaddy's Delta region, this community consists of 21 village customers, and includes 5 CBO (Community Based Organizations) members who are helping to lead the loans in certain area. With this loan, villagers would be able to purchase ducks and good-quality feeds (1 packet costs $12 and is 4 days feed for 100 ducks). For some members, this loan would help to rebuild their unstructured duck farms.  More ducks would let them have increased income from more duck eggs.

Most villagers here are farmers that specialize on cropping as well as seasonal fruits or vegetables. Almost all married women stay as housewives and open grocery stores at home, as well taking care of the home-raised livestock such as ducks, hens or pigs. Some girls work as tailors in the town and come back to the village once in three months.

Picture above are the CBO members Taw Ka Yan Lay Group 2, named U Than (Tu), U Win, U Aung, U Than (T) and U Than (O).  Included in the photo above, U Than (Tu) (in the middle), is 50 years old. He is married and has four children who are still at school. The same as other members, he too is a farmer and has nine acres of crop farm. His wife helps him to look after the ducks and sometimes on the farm too. He currently has 100 ducks. With the loan, he wants to expand up to 150 ducks, which will let him have more income.

loans.use: to help 24 villagers from Taw Ka Yan Lay Village Group 2 purchase ducks as well as to rebuild unstructured duck farm.

borrowers.first_name: Taw Ka Yan Lay Village Group 2

loans.name: Ayuba

texts.en: Ayuba is a maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Ayuba would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest to meet his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Ayuba can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Like other Babban Gona members, Ayuba is looking to earn a better income to provide more food and clothing for his family.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing for his family, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Habila

texts.en: Habila is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Habila joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Nehemiah, Yahaya and Friday.  Before he became a Babban Gona member, Habila would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest to meet his immediate cash needs for food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Habila can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked, Habila  spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to ensure his children have professional jobs.

loans.use: To pay for child school fees and uniforms, thus eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: María Mercedes

texts.es:
EL Grupo De Crédito La Negrita se reúne cada quince días en el Cantón Montecristi, conocido por su rica cultura pre colonial y por su artesanía, que es reconocida a nivel nacional e internacional. Lugar de los famosos sombreros de paja toquilla.
En este lugar vive la señora María, tiene 20 años de edad y mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene dos hijos, uno de 1 año y un bebé de 3 meses de edad. El marido trabaja un bus interprovincial. 
Doña María con la finalidad de obtener sus propios recursos se dedica  a la venta de ropa usada y nueva, tiene un local en su casa donde llega muchas personas cuando lleva mercadería nueva, ella también sale a ofrecer puerta a puerta en sus ratos desocupados y fines de semana, deja a crédito y cobra cada ocho días, ella recibe la ropa en pacas que le envían desde los Estados Unidos, lleva más de 8 años con su negocio con el cual se gana algo que lo utiliza para el bien de su familia.
Este crédito lo va a emplear en comprar pacas de ropa. Es socia del Grupo De Crédito hace 3 ciclos y le gusta por la ayuda que se siempre le brindan con los créditos. Sus metas son tener un local más grande.
texts.en:
The loan group La Negrita meets every fifteen days in the Canton of Montecristi which is known for its rich precolonial culture and artisan products, which are recognized on a national and international level. This place is famous for its woven straw hats.

In this place lives Maria, who is 20 years old and in a domestic partnership. She has two children, one who is 1 year old and a baby who is 3 months old. Her partner works on an inter-province bus.

With the goal of earning her own money, Maria sells used and new clothing. She has a place in her home where many people come when new merchandise arrives. She also goes out door-to-door when it is not busy and on the weekends. She sells on credit and collects payment every 8 days. She receives clothing in packets which arrive from the United States. Maria has been in this business for over 8 years and what she earns she uses to benefit her family.

Maria will use this loan to purchase packets of clothing. She has been a member of this loan group for the past 3 cycles and she likes it because of the help that comes along with the loans. Her goal is to have a larger store.

loans.use: to purchase clothing.

loans.name: Oanh

texts.en: Oanh would like to take a further loan to buy more rice, confectionery and other products to sell from her store. Oanh's previous loan enabled her to increase her sales and earn a higher income to support her family. She hopes that another loan will assist her in increasing the size of her business, attract new customers and increase sales. She also hopes that through the loan she can increase her income and improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy a range of new products such as rice and confectionery.

loans.name: Riza

texts.en:
Riza is a married woman and a mother of two children from Concepcion, Iloilo. She runs a small sari-sari or retail store business selling various goods and items to the people in her place. Riza has been in the business for more than 10 years now.

Riza is asking for a loan to buy more stocks to sell like canned goods, noodles, rice, bread and biscuits, soap and toiletries, condiments, and dry goods like clothes, shoes and slippers. With this, she will be able to improve her stock, allowing her to attract and sell more to her customers.
 
In the future, Riza hopes to make her business a success. Moreover, she wants to save money for her children's schooling.

loans.use: to buy more stocks to sell like canned goods, noodles, rice, bread and biscuits, soap and toiletries, condiments, and dry goods like clothes, shoes and slippers

loans.name: Placida

texts.en:
Placida is 52 years old and married with six children.

Placida works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 5,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional items to sell like canned goods, beverages, groceries, etc.

Placida has borrowed and repaid two loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 22 years and earns additional income from fish vending.
 
Placida aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell like canned goods, beverages, and groceries

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is a married woman with five children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Judith is 36 years old and three of her children are in school.

Judith has a bamboo weaving business in the Philippines. She has requested a 5,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy additional bamboo for weaving.

Judith has been in this business for ten years. In the future, she would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional bamboo for weaving

loans.name: Sarir's Group

texts.en: An old woman living in Kampong Cham province, Sarir is 61 years old and a mother of four children. She can earn income to support her family’s living via rice cropping. She has been involved in this business for 41 years, and it earns her about 34,800 KHR per day. This is Sarir's first time with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). She leads a group of two to get a new loan. As the group leader, she will spend her entire loan portion to buy fertilizer and pay for labor fee. She hopes that she can expand her rice farm as well, to get more income.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pay for labor fee.

location.town: Kampong Cham Province, Koh Sotin District

loans.name: War Kaug Taw Village Group

texts.en:
This community is based in War Kaught Taw Village in Myanmar Ayeyarwaddy's Delta region. It consists of 17 village customers, and includes 5 CBO (Community Based Organization) members who will help to lead the loans in certain area. This loan will help War Kaught Taw villagers to purchase ducks as well as to buy high-quality feeds (1 packet costs $13 and is a week's feed for 100 ducks). It would also help the villagers build a safe farm for ducks. 

The main income is generated by crop farms in the village. Villagers also plant seasonal vegetables such as cucumbers, tomatoes and rosella. They mainly raise ducks, pigs and hens as livestock, and every house has cows as needed for farming.

The picture above is of the CBOs from War Kaught Taw, named Daw Mya, Daw Yin, Daw That, Daw Thin and U Han. Included in the picture, Daw Mya is 28 years old. She is married and blessed with two daughters. She and her husband work on their five acres of crop farm, and also raise ducks, pigs and cows as livestock. Like other fellow members, she wants to buy more ducks that will let her earn more.

loans.use: to purchase ducks, rebuild duck farms and buy high-quality feeds.

loans.name: Pheas' Group

texts.en: Pheas, 25, lives with family members in a rural village of the Prey Veng province. She struggles for a living via rice cropping and working for others for a fee to earn extra income. This is Pheas' first time with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). She leads a group of two members to get a new loan. As the group leader, she will spend her loan portion to buy fertilizer, pesticides and a machine to pump water to support her rice farm. She hopes that she can improve her family condition to be better than before.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticides and a machine to pump water to support her rice farm.

location.town: Prey Veng Province, Sithor Kandal district

loans.name: Pheang's Group

texts.en:
A local resident from Prey Veng province, Pheang is 59 years old and a mother of six children. For her family's living conditions, she can earn income via weaving cotton scarves (Cambodians call them Kror Ma). Moreover, she works for others for a fee to earn more income. She has been involved in this business for ages and it earns her about 34,700 KHR per day. 

In a group of two members, she is the group leader. She will spend her entire loan portion to buy more thread and a bicycle for her grandchild. She hopes that she can improve her family’s living, better than before.

loans.use: to buy more thread and a bicycle for her grandchild.

location.town: Prey Veng Province, Sithor Kandal district

loans.name: Isiyaku Maza

texts.en: Isiyaku Maza is a maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Isiyaku Maza would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater to his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Isiyaku Maza can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Like other Babban Gona members, Isiyaku Maza is looking to earn a better income to provide more food and clothing for his family. He hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: To buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn at low prices during harvest.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy clothes in bulk that he can sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for her certification course for her Bachelors degree in Law.

loans.name: Lanelyn

texts.en: Lanelyn is 49 years old and married with two children who are in school. She works very hard to provide for them. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 5,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stocks of chips, noodles, soft drinks, etc. to sell. She has been in this business for 15 years. In the future, Lanelyn would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of chips, noodles, soft drinks, etc. to sell.

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna is 49 years old and married with seven children.

Myrna works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 8,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like canned goods, shampoo, beverages, etc.

Myrna has borrowed and paid two loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 30 years and also earns an income from food vending.

Myrna aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like canned goods, shampoo, beverages, etc.

loans.name: Sanusi

texts.en: Hello, lenders! Meet Sanusi. He is a micro entrepreneur in East Serang, a suburban city located about three hours’ drive from Jakarta. Sanusi runs a small stall located in front of his family home that sells mobile phone sim cards, mobile phone airtime credits, and utility bill payment service. Sanusi is single; he lives together with his family. He is a hardworking and friendly person. He met a Ruma field staff about six months ago and was excited to become one of Ruma's agents. He decided to join Ruma because he wanted to improve his skills in doing business with mobile technology. As for now, the demand for mobile transactions is increasing and Sanusi hopes to get a working capital loan from Kiva in order to process those transactions.  In the future, Sanusi plans to add one more product from Ruma, which is ‘e-commerce’ for low income communities – a new business model from Ruma that is aimed at helping people get access to good quality of products with better prices. The products range from fashion products, house and kitchen wares, to gadgets and school supplies. To buy one, people only have to choose what they want to buy from the product list in the catalog. After that, they can go to Sanusi or any other certified Ruma agent nearby their houses to make the order and pay. The product will be delivered right to the customer’s door.

loans.use: to provide more mobile services in his community.

loans.name: Barnabas

texts.en: Barnabas is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Barnabas joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Jamila, Mark and Manase.  Before he became a Babban Gona member, Barnabas would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to meet   his immediate cash needs for things such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Barnabas can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked, Barnabas spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to make more money for himself and his family.

loans.use: To pay for child school fees and uniforms, eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Anastacia

texts.en:
Anastacia is a married woman with three children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Anastacia is 65 years old now.

Anastacia has a coffee-making business in the Philippines. Anastacia requested a 6,000 PHP loan amount through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food-production business.

Anastacia has been in this business for 30 years. In the future, Anastacia would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food-production business

loans.name: Lucena

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Lucena works hard to support her family.

She has a cocoa making business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from manicures and pedicures. Lucena is borrowing 5,000 PHP through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food-production business.

Lucena has been sustaining her business activities through her past one loan from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food-production business

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en: Emmanuel is a maize farmer from Kwankwani village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Emmanuel would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest to meet his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Emmanuel can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Emmanuel, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: To buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn at low prices at harvest

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase construction materials to build a new bathroom for the house.

loans.name: Razia

texts.en:
Razia is a 40-year-old married woman. Her husband (also shown in the photo) has been successfully running a small general store for about six years. He has retained many customers over the years and makes a sufficient amount of income to contribute to the family income. 

Razia is a mother of six children, and one of her babies is also shown in the photo. For the improvement of her husband's business, she has availed herself of a Murabaha loan of 30,000 PKR to buy stock of salts, biscuits and beverages to meet customers’ demand time after time for increasing revenues.

loans.use: to buy stocks of salts, biscuits and beverages to meet customers’ demand time after time for increasing revenues.

loans.name: Mbando

texts.en:
Mbando is 38 years old. He is married with five children aged between 2 and 10 years; four of them go to school. He sells cows and has been in a business for 16 years. 

With the loan, he would like to buy more cows for sale. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees for his children.

loans.use: to buy more cows for sale.

loans.name: Eliecer

texts.es: Eliecer, tiene la edad de 47 años, está casado, vive con su esposa y  sus 3 hijos los cuales son mayor prioridad. Con su crédito pretende hacer la compra de fertilizantes, fungicidas y pagar mano de obra en trabajos de asistencia para el café, además de aprovechar la buena fertilidad del suelo y las condiciones de clima y otras que en este tiempo favorecen al cultivo de café. Con estas mejoras al cultivo él espera incrementar sus ganancias y así mejorar las condiciones de vida de su familia, invertir un poco más en el área de cultivo y también cumplir algunas metas. FUDECOSUR le ha brindado el préstamo con mayores facilidades y a una tasa de interés accesible, por lo que él espera cumplir los objetivos planteados con respecto al préstamo.
texts.en: Eliecer, 47, lives with his wife and three children, who are his main priority. With his loan he plans to buy fertilizers, fungicides and to pay laborers for work in his coffee fields. He also hopes to take advantage of the fertility of the land and climatic conditions and other things that are favorable for coffee production right now.  With an improved crop, he hopes to increase his profits and thus improve living conditions for his family. He also hopes by investing a little more in his crop he will meet some of his goals. FUDECOSUR has given him a loan with ease and an accessible interest rate, and he plans to comply with the objectives of his loan.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and fungicides for his coffee crop.

loans.name: Yahaya Dauda

texts.en: Yahaya Dauda is a maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Yahaya Dauda would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to meet his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Yahaya Dauda can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Like other Babban Gona members, Yahaya Dauda is looking to earn a better income to provide more food and clothing for his family, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing. thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Hamisu

texts.en:
Hamisu is a maize farmer from Badamasi village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Hamisu would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest to cater for his immediate cash needs. 

With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Hamisu can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Hamisu, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn at low prices at harvest

loans.name: Blanca Rosa

texts.es: Blanca de 62 años de edad tiene una pequeña tienda ubicada en su lugar de residencia desde hace varios años, tiene muchos clientes por los buenos precios y la amabilidad que tiene a la hora de vender, Blanca está solicitando un crédito para poder comprar más sopas, huevos, granos básicos, refrescos, golosinas, pan dulce, etc. y así poder tener mejores ingresos para una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en: Blanca, 62, has had a small store in her home for many years. She has a lot of customers because of her good prices and her friendliness as a salesperson. Blanca is asking for a loan to buy more soups, eggs, basic grains, sodas, snacks, pastries, etc so that she can make more income and improve her quality of life.

loans.use: to buy more soups, eggs, basic grains, sodas, snacks, pastries, etc.

loans.name: Shadia 3 Group

texts.en:
Reem is the featured borrower of Shadia 3 Group. She is the lady at the far left in the photo with the white top. She joined with the other group members to acquire a loan from Kiva's field partner, Al Majmoua, because they have always been neighbors and they are working hard to develop their business and living.

Reem is a 37-year-old single lady who sells clothes from her house to earn a living and to make sure she can benefit from a financially secure future. She is acquiring a loan from Kiva's field partner, Al Majmoua, to increase her business merchandise with special Christmas and winter collections with special offer prices. She hopes to stay capable of developing her business in a well-managed way to make sure she can respond to diversified customers' needs.

As for the other group members, Dalal is the lady in the center of the photo wearing black, a 69-year-old married mother of three children who runs her own grocery store and mouneh-making business to support her husband in covering their living expenses. Her acquired loan will be invested in developing her business and diversifying their products with special offers. Shadia is the lady at the far right; she is a 35-year-old single lady who is going to invest her current loan to make necessary preparations for the coming winter season.

loans.use: To increase her business merchandise with special Christmas and winter collections

loans.name: Vilma Elsy

texts.es: Vilma vive en casa propia con su esposo, ella se dedica a la elaboración y venta de tortillas desde hace 15 años, su negocio esta ubicado en su lugar de residencia, con las ganancias que tiene logra solventar algunos gastos que se le presentan en su hogar, ella esta solicitando un crédito para la compra de maíz por quintales y cal para continuar con su trabajo.
texts.en: Vilma lives in her own home with her husband. For 15 years she has made and sold tortillas out of her home. With the profits she is able to help with some of the household expenses. She asks for a loan to buy corn in bulk and also to buy lime so that she can continue her work.

loans.use: to buy corn and lime in bulk.

loans.name: Dionicia

texts.es: Dionisia de 45 años de edad es madre soltera vive en casa propia con sus dos hijos y su madre, ella se dedica a la venta de tortillas desde hace 20 años su negocio esta ubicado en su lugar de residencia, ella esta solicitando un crédito para la compra de maíz por mayor y cal para continuar con sus ventas y tener mejores ingresos.
texts.en: Dionicia, 45, is a single mother who lives in her own home with her two children and her mother. For 20 years she has sold tortillas out of her home. She is asking for a loan to buy corn in bulk, and also to buy lime, so that she can continue with her sales and improve her income.

loans.use: to buy corn in bulk, and also to buy lime.

loans.name: Alejandra

texts.es: Alejandra de 47 años de edad vive en casa propia con su grupo familiar, ella posee desde hace 7 años una pequeña tienda ubicada en su lugar de residencia, tiene muchos clientes por los buenos precios y la amabilidad que tiene a la hora de vender, Alejandra está solicitando un crédito para poder comprar más sopas, huevos, granos básicos, refrescos, golosinas, pan dulce, etc. y así poder tener mejores ingresos para una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en: Alejandra, 47, lives in her own home with her family. For 7 years she has run a small store out of her home. She has many customers because of her good prices and friendliness as a salesperson. She is asking for a loan to buy soups, eggs, basic grains, sodas, snacks, pastries, etc so that she can improve her income and her quality of life.

loans.use: to buy more soups, eggs, basic grains, sodas, snacks, pastries, etc.

loans.name: Iliya

texts.en: Iliya is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Iliya joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Emmanuel, Sulaimanu and Firdausi.  Before he became a Babban Gona member, Iliya would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest to meet his immediate cash needs for food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Iliya can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked, Iliya spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to ensure other members of his community are lifted out of poverty.

loans.use: To pay for child school fees and uniforms, thus eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a new engine for the taxi

loans.name: Luz Idalia

texts.es:
La señora Luz Idalia de 30  años de edad, vive con su esposo y su  hija en su casa propia, se dedica desde hace 5 años al negocio de venta de tortillas, sus clientes son sus vecinos los cuales le  prefieren por su buena atención y su buenos producto, vive en una aldea al sur de Honduras, es una mujer emprendedora con deseos de salir adelante que lucha día con día para mejorar su calidad de vida. 
Doña Luz Idalia está solicitando el préstamo para compra de maíz, leña y cal que son los productos más necesarios para la elaboración de las tortillas, con el apoyo de este préstamo pretende mejorar sus ingresos y también su calidad de vida, es un cliente nuevo con deseos de trabajar con Prisma.
Su sueño es aumentar  su clientela para mejorar sus ingresos y al mismo  tiempo mejorar su futuro junto a su familia.

San Lorenzo, Honduras - Noviembre del  2014.
texts.en:
Sra. Luz Idalia is 30 years old and lives in her own home along with her husband and daughter. For the past five years, she has been selling tortillas. Her customers are neighbors who prefer to do business with her because she provides good service and a good product. Luz Idalia lives in a neighborhood in southern Honduras. She is an enterprising woman who wants to succeed, so she strives each day to improve her quality of life.

Doña Luz Idalia is requesting a loan in order to buy corn, firewood, and lime powder. These products are necessary for making tortillas. With the help of this loan, she intends to improve her earnings as well as her quality of life. She is a new client who wants to work with Prisma.

Her dream is to increase her clientele, improve her earnings, and at the same time improve the future for herself and her family.

San Lorenzo, Honduras - November 2014

loans.use: to buy corn, firewood, and lime powder for her business.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Daniel joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Mathew, Ifremu and Lydia.  

Before he became a Babban Gona member, Daniel would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Daniel can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. 

When asked, Daniel  spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to make more money for himself and his family.

loans.use: to pay for school fees and uniforms, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Glenda Liseth

texts.es: Glenda se dedica a la venta de ropa interior para damas y caballeros desde hace varios años, cuenta con muchos clientes fijos, con las ganancias que obtiene de sus ventas logar cubrir algunos gastos de su hogar, Glenda es madre soltera y vive con sus tres hijos, ella esta solicita un crédito para comprar mayor cantidad de ropa interior diferentes precios, estilos y colores y de esta forma contar con más clientes y así mejorar su calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Glenda has sold undergarments for women and men for several years. She has a lot of return customers. With the profits from her sales she is able to cover some of the household expenses.

Glenda is a single mother and lives with her three children. She asks for a loan to buy larger quantities of undergarments at different prices, styles and colors so that she can get more customers and improve her quality of life.

loans.use: to buy larger quantities of undergarments of different prices, styles and colors.

loans.name: 10 De Diciembre  (Portoviejo) Group

texts.es:
En  el sector conocido como Estancia Vieja en la parroquia Colon  de la ciudad de Portoviejo se reúnen  cada quince días las socias  del Grupo De Crédito 10 De Diciembre. Lugar de gente humilde y dedicada a la agricultura y al comercio en general. Ellos decidieron unirse para poder acceder a los beneficios que presta la institución y con los créditos  mejorar  sus negocios.
Una de las socias de este grupo es la señora Luz, tiene 28 años de edad, mantiene una relación de unión libre y de esta relación tienen 3 hijos, de 10 y 9 años y un bebé de 8 meses. Los dos mayores estudian en escuela. Su esposo es supervisor de seguridad.
Doña Luz al ver que a su esposo no le alcanza con lo que el gana para sacar adelante a su familia decidió trabajar para ayudar en los gastos del hogar, ella se dedica al comercio, vende productos de Avon (artículos de belleza, cosméticos perfumería y accesorios para damas). Su forma de venta es puerta a puerta, sale dos o tres veces por semana a ofrecer sus productos los mismos que deja a crédito y cobra por semanas, lleva dos años dedicada a esta actividad con lo cual sale adelante. 
Este crédito lo va a emplear en comprar perfumes y cremas. Está en el Grupo De Crédito desde el inicio  y le gusta por la ayuda de los créditos. Sus sueños son seguir adelante.
texts.en:
In an area known as Estancia Vieja in the parish of Colon and the city of Portoviejo, a lending group called 10 De Diciembre meets every 15 days. This place is known for humble people who work in agriculture and commerce. The group decided to come together so that they could access the benefits of this institution and use the loans to improve their businesses.

One of the members of the group is Luz, 28, who is married and has three children ages 10, 9 and 8 months The older two are in school. Her husband is a security supervisor. Luz saw that what he made wasn't enough to get the family ahead, and so she decided to work in order to help out with household expenses. She is a merchant, selling Avon products (beauty, cosmetics, perfume and accessories for women). She sells door to door, going out two or three times a week to offer her products. She leaves them on credit and collects payment every week. She has been doing this for two years and is making progress.

This loan will be used to buy perfumes and lotions. She has been part of the lending group since its inception and likes it because the loans are helpful. Her dream is to keep moving forward.

loans.use: to buy perfumes and lotions.

loans.name: Elenilson Antonio

texts.es: Elenilson de 36 años de edad vive en casa propia con su hijo, el posee una venta de repuestos nuevos y usados para vehículos desde hace 10 años, su negocio lo tiene ubicado en su lugar de residencia, el esta solicitando un crédito para la compra de mas repuestos por mayor y asi continuar con sus ventas y tener mejores ingresos.
texts.en:
Elenilson is 36 years old and resides in his own home along with his son. He has a shop where he has been selling new and used vehicle parts for 10 years. His business is located at his place of residence.

The loan he is requesting will be used to buy more spare parts in bulk so that he can continue his sales and have a better income.

loans.use: to buy spare parts in bulk.

loans.name: Esterlita

texts.en:
Esterlita is 53 years old and has seven children. Esterlita is married and all of her children are in school.

Esterlita is in the agricultural business in the Philippines. Esterlita requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

Esterlita has been in this business for five years now, and she has borrowed eight times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Esterlita would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Elvira works hard to support her family.

She has a fishing business in the Philippines, and she also earns additional income from raising pigs. Elvira is borrowing PHP 5,000 through NWTF to buy fish nets and other fishing materials for her fishing business.

Elvira has been sustaining her business activities through her past two loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fish nets and other fishing materials

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet is a married woman with three children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Juliet is 30 years old and all of her children are in school.

Juliet has a food vending business in the Philippines. Juliet requested a PHP 5,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy ingredients for her business.
